content:
<?php
/**
 * Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
 * the standard input according to the problem statement.
 **/

fscanf(STDIN, "%d", $N);

$s = $N.'' ;
$ar = str_split($s) ;

$numbers = [] ;
$result = 0 ;

for($k = 0 ; $k< count($ar) ; $k++)
{
    $digit1 = $ar[$k] ;
        $i = $digit1 ;
        $i = intval($i) ;
        if($i%3 == 0 && !in_array($i, $numbers))
        {
     
                  $result+= $i ;
        }
        if($k+1 != count($ar))
        {
            $digit2 = $ar[$k + 1] ;
        $i = $digit1.$digit2 ;
        $i = intval($i) ;
        if($i%3 == 0 && !in_array($i, $numbers))
        {
            $result+= $i ;
        }
        }
        

}


// Write an answer using echo(). DON'T FORGET THE TRAILING \n
// To debug: error_log(var_export($var, true)); (equivalent to var_dump)


echo $result ;
?>

Comment: Good and easy problem.
Perhaps could rephrase the sum of 1 or 2 consecutive digits to be:
sum of numbers made of 1 or 2 consecutive digits

> 1 or 2 successive digits

Can you define this?

This is the third time today you have submitted this.
You can use "Edit" instead of creating a new submission each time.

Yes you are right but when I do edit even if I have not modified anything and I click on send always i get error in the first test case, although it works in the IDE for this reason I created a new one..

maybe I didn't explain well, I wanted to say if in a number you find 1 or 2 consecutive digits divisible by 3  return thier sum.
ex:
$r = 0
N = 654 
 6%3 = 0  => $r = $r +6 (this is for the one degit)
65 %3 != 0
5%3 != 0
54 %3 = 0  => $r = $r+54 = 60 (this is for the 2 consecutive degit)
4%3 != 0
so the result  60.

Thanks,
I did not explain well for the description I will correct it because not limited to 2 digits.. for any sequence of successive digits

why you applied for your solution here ?
it's not a good idea
Anyway thank you for your solution but your it was very long normally it does not exceed 10 lines of code

It is not all successive digits...
Your test cases are all only considering up to 2 digits,

like 6587002.
If you consider more than two than 8700 is also a factor of 3

yes you are right thank you again.
maybe I will work on this to have a list of all consecutive digits

Your solution fails because you reference the variable N before defining it - you're missing the fscanf(STDIN, "%d", $N);
You also need to a <?php at the start and ?> at the end of your code.
